content.text: Structured Editor
A bit about this editor environment

This tutorial takes place in a structured editor, which has some important differences from a standard text editor. The "structured" part refers to the fact that the editor's "source of truth" representation of your source code is not a long sequence of utf-8 characters, but rather "structured data".

For many structured editors, the structure of the data is the Abstract Syntax Tree (AST) of the given programming language. Typical programming languages have node types for expressions (variables, numbers, strings, function application, lambdas, array & object literals, infix boolean and prefix unary operators), statements (control structures such as
if
for
, and
while
, function and class declaration), and, types (type variables, type application).

This has the downside of being quite complicated; both on the implementation side (ensuring that rendering, formatting, and editing each node type works as intended is a huge job) but more importantly: there's a lot of mental overhead for the user, because key strokes might do different things depending on what kind of Node your cursor is in, so you have to be aware of what kind of node (out of dozens of types) you are currently editing.

In an attempt to avoid these downsides, this editor works on what I call the "Concrete Syntax Tree"; essentially lisp s-expressions (identifiers, strings, lists, and arrays). In my opinion, this strikes a nice balance between the benefits you get from moving beyond "a jumble of text characters in a file" while still keeping the representation simple enough that it doesn't get in the way of the editing experience.
Here's an example of some syntax in this structured editor:
And here's some structured code! Feel free to play around with it; everything on this page is editable.
The Concrete Syntax Tree
Let's familiarize ourselves with the kinds of syntax we'll be working with: the "Concrete Syntax Tree". The "evaluator" for this page is set to
REPR
, which simply outputs the JSON representation of the CST for a given toplevel term.
Here's the TypeScript type of a CST node (abbreviated to include only the variants that our parser will be concerned with).
About the editor
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in evaluation is analyzing eveything and arranging them into dependency order. This two-level structure leads to a "literate programming" experience that I find quite pleasant.

rich-text
block, which gets treated as a comment.

it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or as m
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or as makes up mo
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or as makes up most of this
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)

it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or as makes up most of this document, a ric
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or as makes up most of this document, a rich-text
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)

If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. T
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressi
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.

(If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

(If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the l
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing

navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of n
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no di
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)

navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no different
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the

will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the fir
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in eva
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in evaluation i
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in evaluation is analyzi
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)

The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in evaluation is analyzing eveyrh
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)

Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in evaluation is analyzing eveyy
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)

The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in evaluation is analyzing eveything
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)

Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in evaluation is analyzing eveything and arran
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in evaluation is analyzing eveything and arranging them
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)

(If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in evaluation is analyzing eveything and arranging them into dep
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in evaluation is analyzing eveything and arranging them into dependency o
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in evaluation is analyzing eveything and arranging them into dependency order. two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in evaluation is analyzing eveything and arranging them into dependency order. This two-lev
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)

to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in evaluation is analyzing eveything and arranging them into dependency order. This two-level struct
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in evaluation is analyzing eveything and arranging them into dependency order. This two-level structure lead
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)

meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in evaluation is analyzing eveything and arranging them into dependency order. This two-level structure leads to a "l

will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in evaluation is analyzing eveything and arranging them into dependency order. This two-level structure leads to a "literate p
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)
There are
two levels

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in evaluation is analyzing eveything and arranging them into dependency order. This two-level structure leads to a "literate programmi
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in evaluation is analyzing eveything and arranging them into dependency order. This two-level structure leads to a "literate programming" expre
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)

The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in evaluation is analyzing eveything and arranging them into dependency order. This two-level structure leads to a "literate programming" exper
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)

This two-level structure leads to a "literate programming" experience tha
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)

Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. This two-level structure leads to a "literate programming" experience that I find
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)

of nesting. First, there is a collapsible tree of "toplevel nodes", used for broad organization and presentation. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in evaluation is analyzing eveything and arranging them into dependency order. This two-level structure leads to a "literate programming" experience that I find quite pl
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)

Each toplevel node then contains a concrete syntax tree that might represent a toplevel expression, a value or type definition, or, as makes up most of this document, a rich-text block. The order of toplevel expressions in the document, or the level of nesting, makes no difference to the compiler; the first step in evaluation is analyzing eveything and arranging them into dependency order. This two-level structure leads to a "literate programming" experience that I find quite pleasin.
Some notable features of this structured editor:
it's impossible to have "unbalanced parenthesis" or a "missing close-quote". Deleting a close-paren deletes the whole group.
code formatting is automatic (a la prettier)

AST locations are much more precise than "line & column". Adding code before or after a given identifier doesn't cause the editor to "lose track of it"; e.g. error underlines & hover information are trivially preserved.
we can attach
meta-data
to individual AST nodes; for example marking a node that we would like to be "traced" during the next execution.

rendering gets more interesting! This rich text block you're reading is technically a comment (as far as the compiler is concerned). Later on you'll see the "fixture test render plugin", which takes a toplevel expression of a certain form and renders a nice table of inputs & outputs, highlighting any tests that are failing.
navigation has lots of nice affordances; e.g. typing
will take you to the end of whatever s-expression your cursor is currently inside of.

crucially, I've put a lot of effort into making the typing experience as un-surprising as possible. If you're looking at some code, typing in each of the characters of the plain-text representation in order results in that code getting reproduced in the CST. (If you're tried any other structured editors before, you'll know that this is rarely the case!)

Structure Editor
A bit about this editor environment
Structured Editor
A bit about this editor environment

This tutorial takes place in a structured editor, which has some important differences from a standard text editor. The "structured" part refers to the fact that the editor's "source of truth" representation of your source code is not a long sequence of utf-8 characters, but rather "structured data". For many structured editors, the structure of the data is the Abstract Syntax Tree (AST) of the given programming language. Typical programming languages have node types for expressions (variables, numbers, strings, function application, lambdas, array & object literals, infix boolean and prefix unary operators), statements (control structures such as
if
for
, and
while
, function and class declaration), and, types (type variables, type application).

This has the downside of being quite complicated; both on the implementation side (ensuring that rendering, formatting, and editing each node type works as intended is a huge job) but more importantly: there's a lot of mental overhead for the user, because key strokes might do different things depending on what kind of Node your cursor is in, so you have to be aware of what kind of node (out of dozens of types) you are currently editing.

In an attempt to avoid these downsides, this editor works on what I call the "Concrete Syntax Tree"; essentially lisp s-expressions (identifiers, strings, lists, and arrays). In my opinion, this strikes a nice balance between the benefits you get from moving beyond "a jumble of text characters in a file" while still keeping the representation simple enough that it doesn't get in the way of the editing experience.
